My problem with anthropogenic climate change theory is that it is all based on computer models, and these cannot be verified to be correct over long tiem spans. I know someone wil jump in here saying how it’s all verified, but there is simply no way. The climate is too complex to model. Anyone in engineering knows how very complex even simple computer models are, like those computing NVH (essentially noise in automobiles). Those programs require a lot of validation, and they are not perfect. The climate is orders-of-magnitude more complex than that. Here’s a simple story that illustrates the point. Back after Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait, American scientists, led by Carl Sagan (a patron saint of lefty scientists) predicted that if we tried to liberate Kuwait, Hussein would torch the oil fields, and the resulting soot would float through the atmosphere, creating something analogous to a “nuclear winter.” A nuclear winter was a concept that a nuclear war would stir up so much dust into the atmosphere that it would block enough of the sun’s rays to cool the earth: no crops would grow and we would all starve. Well, Sagan & Co, were half right. Hussein did indeed torch the oil fields, and it was pretty smoky before we got it all extinguished. But there was no nuclear winter. Sagan and Co. had forgotten about rain, which washed the skies clear before the soot could get to the upper reaches of the atmosphere. And that was that. I see climate change as the same “The sky is falling mantra.” And of course you have to understand that the “vast majority of scientists who agree on climate change” know on which side their bread is buttered. How many grants are offered to climate change deniers? As in everything else, “Follow the money.”

It’s 620AM. Martha wakes up & as she rubs her eyes, she checks out the window to see if there’s sunshine. There isn’t. As if the morning sun shining bright would make a difference. It was winter after all and winters for Martha seemed forever gloomy. And then there was the universal dilemma on what to wear. It was heavily tilted towards what not to wear but nevertheless a dilemma, especially when it came to warm clothing. To add to it, over the past one week she had been sensing a growing pain in her lower back. She had wondered even whilst at work and dismissed thoughts of the chair or her work posture being a reason for it. She had attended a seminar on ergonomic hygiene and the brand that was advertised was the equipment she rested her hands or bum on, Monday to Friday. She heard her husband shuffle in his bed, as she scrambled on the side table to find her glasses. It was just a shuffle. He wouldn’t be waking up until a good 45 minutes more and his alarm had a name, Martha. A mother of two children aged 6 and 12, and an IT professional just like anyone else who could open their mouth and continue to speak in jargons that keep changing every year. The alarm even went on to deliver a cup of coffee for his sleepy eyes, and a cup of milk each for the tiny tots, every single morning. Time was of essence for Martha and somehow, the morning minutes seemed to pass like weekends, skidding away. But waking up was never a problem for Martha. It was as if her body had invisible sensors that activated her conscience against the problems to be, if she were to wake up a few minutes late, on weekdays. Her body clock had been tuned immaculately over the past several years, and was like clockwork by this time. Even a regular clock or a watch had to be corrected as per daylight savings at least once a year, but not hers. It had even adjusted to the fact that on Saturday’s and Sunday’s she could sleep until 0730AM. An hour more of priceless sleep. And most people keep getting fascinated by science, she thought. They must think more of a mother’s life-science. There’s lay a sea of lessons for Mankind in it, she thought. Her son Malloy and daughter Olive were abundant kids. Abundant not to say financially but in displaying extreme levels of raw energy. They could go on u til their eyelids had to be closed by her thumb at night but of late she had found a solution in Batman & Dora sleep masks. They seemed to have done the trick. There were times when Martha & Andrew (spouse) would spend a minute in minus temperatures, explaining to a unsuspecting host the possibility of things breaking or bending or shattering during their visit. They would however allay the fears that they would try to not to let it happen and were kind enough to offer damage compensation. It was the best they could do if they had to have some semblance of socializing, outside their home. It was 715AM by the time she had prepared breakfast & lunch for the day. At times she would be looked upon in astonishment when she claimed to get food ready for the day in less than an hour. Weave a web of ‘things to do’ in front of a Mom, shelve her time in half & ask her to do what she can. She will find a way to do her best, for it’s her kids on the line, doesn’t matter if she can’t rest. There is no other relationship that conquers discomfort, like motherhood does. As she yelled at her neutron and proton to be on the breakfast couch for their morning nibble, she felt a twitch in her back just as she picked up a shoe from the kitchen floor. Andrew was lenient & had let the kids choose the couch for breakfast instead of a table, as a reward for finishing what’s given as breakfast. Malloy was a good negotiator but his genes were from his Dad so he had to give in. Give in to the lack of experience that is. He was learning that experience was necessary even on top of sheer brilliance. Martha ignored the pain and smiled as Olive raised her empty glass of milk in a show of pride. As is usually the case, sensibility started to grow in her daughter and her abundant energy started to be challenged into sports, mainly in tennis & swimming. Malloy on the other hand was a stubborn kid. He was extremely logic driven and had a tendency to try & trod the crevices around house rules, as a way of flexing his negotiating muscles. His parents as well read as they were, knew that he was mastering the art of denial. An act done knowingly, with a knowledge that the risks involved are not proven on paper. Or the associated risks have plenty a contradicting arguments, leaving open a strand or two of doubt open for the risk not being a risk at all. He had been told to not use his smart phone for more than 4 hours a day. It had been a few days of negotiation to arrive at that number. Yet when the notification popped up every Sunday noon, he would average 7 hours on most weeks. He lived in denial that the screen time did not have an adverse effect on him & to his advantage, he had good grades at school to show for. There were visible dark circles by now and he continued to be in denial, being the stubborn child that he was. His body was taking a toll but due to his metabolism & battery of energy, there wasn’t anything other than the dark circles to blame, yet. He was also in his school skateboarding acrobat team. And he attributed the dark circles to lack of melanin in his skin & was currently experimenting with a lotion that seemed to be working for his friends at school. Their dark circles, unlike Malloy were not from Late night hours spent reading up Wikipedia or listening to podcasts on how stuff works. Gaming was their thing that kept them awake at night. This morning, an argument broke out when Andrew snatched Malloy’s phone as he spilled food over the carpet, while reading a blog explaining what made a bottle of carbonated drink fly in the air when shaken rigorously. Martha came in defense of Malloy & bent over to clean up the carpet and that’s when everyone in the household became aware of her discomfort in the back. Fast forward a few hours & Martha was busy attending a conference call and when it ended, she had received approval for a staggered development plan for a software release, which was originally approved to occur in one go. Life goes on, for as long as there is ignorance. Change happens when there is acceptance. Why the story? To draw an analogy. Martha, the Mom = Mother Earth (Relentlessly strives to give all forms of species a chance at experiencing the bliss called life. Keeps taking in everything dumped onto her, and of late into her core, in the form of plastic, cordoned off polluted rivers, radiation zones, co2 and the list goes on).  Malloy the boy = Humankind, us (Believing in our ability to overcome any and every problem through the lens of technological advancement, believing that there’s a cure to every symptom, like he believed he could continue to sleep less, continue to grow smarter, & use a quick fix to get rid of his dark circles) Olive the daughter = Other species on Earth (The silent spectator. Knowing & understanding everything that was going on around, yet finding oneself helpless, yet evolving in newer ways to adopt to the change, or hoping to) Malloy’s friends at School - Anti-climate change enthusiasts (The ignorant, or the ones backed by the ones with vested commercial interests. Propagating an idea that all is good & there’s a cure for everything, a problem to every solution, often getting the minds mixed with neatly laced facts, like the idea of a lotion that could rid Malloy of his dark circles). Andrew, the Dad - The Government (Aware of everything that’s going on, being observant, making inferences, drawing plans, battling opposition, finding funds, counting on scientists hard at work to crack the next solution. Often blamed for not having an intent to change things, but being intent-filled yet finding it hard to convince of the good being done, for there’s so much to be done). Martha’s Back pain = floods, droughts, forest fires, global warming, rising sea levels/temperatures, vanishing of coral reefs. Anti-climate change - Kids at school (Providing an alibi (melanin dose) - wrongly believing it works & that there’s nothing about to happen from lack of sleep at a young formative years). Climate change is real. The signs are too evident to ignored or to try and justify. Like visible dark circles that can be hidden only temporarily. Any argument trying to prove that climate change isn’t real, is akin to Malloy’s art of denial. And we don’t have to wait for Mother Earth to keep showing more and worse forms of pain, for she deserves some respite too.

First, you need to separate two entirely different questions, which are commonly stirred together. 1 - Is climate change (a sometimes weasel-wording change from global warming) real? Apparently yes. Of course, a certain amount of humility is in order - during the 50s to 70s the measured global average was going down, and climatologists were worried that we were heading into another ice age. Which, from the proxy record, is about due. Nonetheless, we do a much better job of data collection than we did 50 years ago, and the current warming seems not to be a temporary thing. 2 - (and this is where things get tricky) Is the increased warming caused by people? That is, what fraction is anthropogenic? This is potentially more problematic. It is clear that atmospheric CO2 is increasing due to human activity, and an excellent case has been made to link the two. A mechanism has been proposed (greenhouse gas) which is quite convincing. But. There is a fundamental issue that is never addressed. “If there were no human-caused changes, such as CO2 emissions, what would the climate be like?” And there is no easy way to determine this, since we have no way of measuring climate in the absence of the anthropogenic influences which have been identified. That computer models predict warming is not actually a guarantee that the models are correct, only that they have been properly tuned to give results which seem reasonable.
